ğŸ”½ ğŸ”½ Summary of the Chapter and Its NameğŸ”½ Here are summaries of the following three matters: the way in which the objectğŸ”½ of negation refuted in this chapter is grasped, what is established after it isğŸ”½ ğŸ”½ refuted through arguments, and in light of that, how to posit causes, conditions, and effects.
When such things as seeds and fuel are seen or heard to beğŸ”½ performing the action of giving rise to such things as sprouts and ï¬re, respectively, to take both cause and effect not as merely nominally imputed, but asğŸ”½ the objects that are the bases of nominal imputation, grasped as inherentlyğŸ”½ existent produced and producer, is to grasp the object of negation.
ğŸ”½ When the object so grasped is maintained to exist in that way, through anğŸ”½ analysis asking whether this arisen effect has the same essence as or a differentğŸ”½ essence from its causes and conditions, with respect to the effect, the essenceğŸ”½ of the produced is refuted, and when one analyzes the conditions that produceğŸ”½ the effect, asking whether they exist or not when the cause occurs, then withğŸ”½ respect to the cause the essence of the producers is refuted. [
This is becauseğŸ”½ NaÌ„gaÌ„rjuna presents a position, the primary focus of which is refutation, according to which an inherently existent entity cannot be posited as havingğŸ”½ causes, conditions, or effects.
ğŸ”½ Here is why he does this: Since from beginningless time, we are accustomed to grasping causes and effects as existing inherently, this is difï¬cult toğŸ”½ dispel.
When that essence is refuted, the tenability of action and agent in theğŸ”½ context of essencelessness can easily be established.
NaÌ„gaÌ„rjuna does not focusğŸ”½ here primarily on how we set out action and agent conventionally in our ownğŸ”½ system.
ğŸ”½ Arguments such as â€œNeither from itself nor from anotherâ€ that expressğŸ”½ refutations always involve analysis of how the objects taken to be the bases ofğŸ”½ conventional imputation exist. Therefore, they refute any arising that is notğŸ”½ merely imputed, but they do not refute mere arising.
